text:
Standard 1: History and the Nature of Science (SC.S.1)
  • demonstrate an understanding of the history of science and the enviroment of scientific knowledge,
  • demonstrate an understanding of science as a human endeavor encompassing the contributions of diverse cultures and scientists, and
  • demonstrate an understanding of the nature of science.

children.text: History and the Nature of Science Objectives
SC.K.1.1  Students will ask questions about themselves and their world.
SC.K.1.2  Students will listen to stories about the lives and discoveries of scientists.
SC.1.1.1 Students will  ask questions about themselves and their world.
SC.1.1.2 Students will discuss the lives and discoveries of scientists after listening to stories about their lives and discoveries.
SC.2.1.1 Students will recognize science as the human's search for an understanding of the world by asking questions about themselves and their world.
SC.2.1.2 Students will discuss the lives and discoveries of scientists of different cultures and backgrounds.
SC.2.1.3 Students will identify and discuss the role of community people in science careers.
SC.3.1.1 Students will recognize that scientific explanations may lead to new discoveries (e.g., new knowledge leads to new questions).
SC.3.1.2 Students will study the lives and discoveries of scientists of different cultures and backgrounds.
SC.3.1.3 Students will explore science careers in the community.
SC.4.1.1 Students will contrast changes in scientific knowledge resulting from new discoveries (e.g., new knowledge leads to new questions).
SC.4.1.2 Students will study the lives and discoveries of scientists of different cultures and backgrounds.
SC.4.1.3 Students will explore science careers in West Virginia.
SC.5.1.1 Students will realize that scientists formulate and test their explanations of nature using observation and experiments.
SC.5.1.2  Students will recognize scientific knowledge is subject to modification as new scientific information challenges current explanations.
SC.5.1.3  Students will examine the careers and contributions of men and women of diverse cultures to the development of science
SC.5.1.4  Students will articulate the historical significance of scientific discoveries.
SC.6.1.1  Students will explain that scientists formulate and test their explanations of nature using observation and experiments.
SC.6.1.2  Students will recognize that scientific knowledge is subject to modification as new scientific information challenges current theories.
SC.6.1.3  Students will examine the careers and contributions of men and women of diverse cultures to the development of science.

SC.6.1.4  Students will articulate the historical significance of scientific discoveries as influenced by technological demands, competition, controversy, world events, personalities and societal issues.
SC.7.1.1 Students will realize that scientists formulate and test their explanations of nature using observation, experiments and theoretical models.
SC.7.1.2  Students will recognize and appreciate that scientific knowledge is subject to modification as new scientific information challenges current theories.
SC.7.1.3  Students will examine the careers and contributions of men and women of diverse cultures to the development of science.

SC.7.1.4 Students will  articulate the historical significance of scientific discoveries as influenced by technological demands, competition, controversy, world events, personalities and societal issues.
SC.8.1.1  Students will realize that scientists formulate and test their explanations of nature using observation, experiments and theoretical models.
SC.8.1.2 Students will  recognize and appreciate that scientific knowledge is subject to modification as new scientific information challenges current theories.
SC.8.1.3  Students will examine the careers and contributions of men and women of diverse cultures to the development of science.

SC.8.1.4  Students will articulate the historical significance of scientific discoveries as influenced by technological demands, competition, controversy, world events, personalities and societal issues.
SC.9.1.1 Students will formulate scientific explanations based on the student's observational and experimental evidence, accounting for variability in experimental results.
SC.9.1.2 Students will  recognize that science has practical and theoretical limitations.
SC.9.1.3  Students will recognize that science is based on a set of observations in a testable framework that demonstrate basic laws that are consistent.
SC.9.1.4 Students will  conclude that science is a blend of creativity, logic and mathematics.
SC.9.1.5 Students will  trace the development of key historical concepts and principles describing their impact on modern thought and life by identifying the scientist's contributions.
SC.10.1.1 Students will  formulate scientific explanations based on historical observations and experimental evidence, accounting for variability in experimental results.
SC.10.1.2 Students will  recognize that science has practical and theoretical limitations.
SC.10.1.3  Students will recognize that science is based on a set of observations in a testable framework that demonstrate basic laws that are consistent.
SC.10.1.4  Students will conclude that science is a blend of creativity, logic and mathematics.
SC.10.1.5 Students will  trace the development of key historical concepts and principles describing their impact on modern thought and life by identifying the scientist's contributions.

text:
Standard 2: Science as Inquiry (SC.S.2)
  • demonstrate the abilities necessary to do scientific inquires,
  • demonstrate understanding about scientific inquiry, and
  • demonstrate the ability to think and act as scientists by engaging in active inquiries, investigations and hands-on activities a minimum of 50% of the instructional time.

children.text: Science as Inquiry Objectives

SC.K.2.1  Students will demonstrate curiosity, initiative and creativity by asking questions about the environment noting patterns and variations of natural objects (e.g., trees, leaves, animal structures).
SC.K.2.2  Students will explore and describe objects and events using the five senses to develop observational skills and make predictions based on personal observation.
SC.K.2.3  Students will use scientific instruments and everyday materials to investigate the natural world (e.g., hand lens, balance, magnets).

SC.K.2.4  Students will use safe and proper techniques for handling, manipulating and caring for science materials (e.g., follow safety rules, maintain a clean work area, treat living organisms humanely).
SC.K.2.5  Students will collect and record information in a variety of ways (e.g., drawings, weather calendar, graphs).
SC.1.2.1 Students will demonstrate curiosity, initiative and creativity by questioning observations of changes in the environment (e.g., life cycles; motion of celestial objects; sun and shadow).
SC.1.2.2 Students will use scientific instruments and everyday materials to investigate the natural world (e.g., hand lens, balance, magnets, thermometer, seeds, rocks).

SC.1.2.3 Students will use safe and proper techniques for handling, manipulating and caring for science materials (e.g., follow safety rules, maintain a clean work area, treat living organisms humanely).

SC.1.2.4 Students will collect, record and compare information using a variety of classification systems (e.g., ordering, sorting, sequencing) and using a variety of communication techniques (e.g., sketches, pictographs, models).
SC.2.2.1 Students will demonstrate curiosity, initiative and creativity by observing, classifying and comparing the patterns, variations and interactions of natural objects in the environment.

SC.2.2.2 Students will manipulate scientific instruments and everyday materials to investigate the natural world (e.g., hand lens, balance, thermometer, metric ruler, magnets, weather instruments, calculators).
SC.2.2.3 Students will measure the length and width of various objects using standard and non-standard units (e.g., metric ruler, paper clips, counting bears).

SC.2.2.4 Students will use safe and proper techniques for handling, manipulating, and caring for science materials (e.g., follow safety rules, maintain a clean work area, treat living organisms humanely).

SC.2.2.5 Students will conduct simple investigations; observe, collect and record information using a variety of classification systems; describe trends of data; and make predictions based on that data (e.g., seasonal changes and plants; temperature and weather).
SC.3.2.1 Students will demonstrate curiosity, initiative and creativity by planning and conducting simple investigations.
SC.3.2.2 Students will recognize that developing solutions to problems takes time, patience and persistence through individual and cooperative ventures.
SC.3.2.3 Students will support statements with facts found through research in reference books, science-related magazines and the Internet.

SC.3.2.4 Students will use scientific instruments and everyday materials to investigate the natural world (e.g., graduated cylinder, hand lens, metric ruler, magnets, weather instruments, thermometer, calculators).

SC.3.2.5 Students will use safe and proper techniques for handling, manipulating and caring for science materials (e.g., follow safety rules, maintain a clean work area, treat living organisms humanely).
SC.3.2.6 Students will apply mathematical skills and use metric units in measurements.
SC.3.2.7 Students will interpret data presented in a table, graph, map or diagram and use it to answer questions and make predictions and inferences based on patterns of evidence.
SC.3.2.8 Students will test variables (e.g., those that affect plant growth; speed; action of water on soil; shadow formation)

SC.4.2.1 Students will demonstrate curiosity, initiative and creativity by developing questions that lead to investigations; designing simple experiments; and trusting observations of discoveries when trying new tasks and skills.
SC.4.2.2 Students will recognize that developing solutions to problems requires persistence, flexibility, openmindedness, and alertness for the unexpected.
SC.4.2.3 Students will support statements with facts found through research in reference books, science-related magazines, multimedia and the Internet.

SC.4.2.4 Students will use scientific instruments and everyday materials to investigate the natural world (e.g., hand lens, telescope, thermometer, balances, magnets, tuning forks, bulbs and batteries, graduated cylinders, calculators, computers).
SC.4.2.5 Students will demonstrate safe and proper techniques for handling, manipulating and caring for science materials.
SC.4.2.6 Students will construct a hypothesis when provided a problem.
SC.4.2.7 Students will establish variables and controls in an experiment; test variables through experimentation.
SC.4.2.8 Students will interpret data presented in a table, graph, or diagram and use it to answer questions and make decisions.

SC.4.2.9 Students will draw and support conclusions, make predictions and inferences based on patterns of evidence (e.g., weather maps, change of speed in a given amount of time, change in wave motions with changes in energy, variation of plants).
SC.4.2.10 Students will apply mathematical skills and use metric units in measurements and calculations.
SC.5.2.1  Students will cooperate and collaborate to ask questions, find answers, solve problems, conduct investigations to further an appreciation of scientific discovery.
SC.5.2.2  Students will formulate conclusions through close observations, logical reasoning, objectivity, perseverance and integrity in data collection.
SC.5.2.3  Students will apply skepticism, careful methods, logical reasoning and creativity in investigating the observable universe.

SC.5.2.4  Students will use a variety of materials and scientific instruments to conduct explorations, investigations and experiments of the natural world (e.g., barometer, anemometer, microscope, computer).
SC.5.2.5  Students will demonstrate safe techniques for handling, manipulating and caring for science materials, equipment, natural specimens and living organisms.

SC.5.2.6  Students will utilize experimentation to demonstrate scientific processes and thinking skills (e.g., formulating questions, predicting, forming hypotheses, quantifying, identifying dependent and independent variables).
SC.5.2.7  Students will construct and use charts, graphs and tables to organize, display, interpret, analyze and explain data.
SC.5.2.8  Students will use inferential reasoning to make logical conclusions from collected data.
SC.6.2.1  Students will cooperate and collaborate to ask questions, find answers, solve problems, conduct investigations to further an appreciation of scientific discovery.
SC.6.2.2  Students will formulate conclusions through close observations, logical reasoning, objectivity, perseverance and integrity in data collection.
SC.6.2.3  Students will apply skepticism, careful methods, logical reasoning and creativity in investigating the observable universe.

SC.6.2.4  Students will use a variety of materials and scientific instruments to conduct explorations, investigations and experiments of the natural world (e.g., barometer, anemometer, microscope, computer).
SC.6.2.5  Students will demonstrate safe techniques for handling, manipulating and caring for science materials, equipment, natural specimens and living organisms.

SC.6.2.6  Students will utilize experimentation to demonstrate scientific processes and thinking skills (e.g., formulating questions, predicting, forming hypotheses, quantifying, identifying dependent and independent variables).
SC.6.2.7  Students will construct and use charts, graphs and tables to organize, display, interpret, analyze and explain data.
SC.6.2.8  Students will use inferential reasoning to make logical conclusions from collected data.
SC.6.2.9  Students will use appropriate technology solutions to gather data; graph data; interpret data; and analyze information.
SC.7.2.1  Students will cooperate and collaborate to ask questions, find answers, solve problems, conduct investigations to further an appreciation of scientific discovery.
SC.7.2.2  Students will formulate conclusions through close observations, logical reasoning, objectivity, perseverance and integrity in data collection.
SC.7.2.3  Students will examine the role of skepticism, careful methods, logical reasoning and creativity in investigating the observable universe.

SC.7.2.4  Students will use a variety of materials and scientific instruments to conduct explorations, investigations and experiments of the natural world (e.g., barometer, anemometer, microscope, computer).
SC.7.2.5  Students will demonstrate safe techniques for handling, manipulating and caring for science materials, equipment, natural specimens and living organisms.

SC.7.2.6  Students will utilize experimentation to demonstrate scientific processes and thinking skills (e.g., formulating questions, predicting, forming hypotheses, quantifying, identifying dependent and independent variables).
SC.7.2.7  Students will construct and use charts, graphs and tables to organize, display, interpret, analyze and explain data.
SC.7.2.8  Students will use appropriate technology solutions to gather data; graph data; interpret data; and analyze information.
SC.7.2.9  Students will use inferential reasoning to make logical conclusions from collected data.
SC.8.2.1  Students will cooperate and collaborate to ask questions, find answers, solve problems, conduct investigations to further an appreciation of scientific discovery.
SC.8.2.2  Students will formulate conclusions through close observations, logical reasoning, objectivity, perseverance and integrity in data collection.
SC.8.2.3  Students will apply skepticism, careful methods, logical reasoning and creativity in investigating the observable universe.

SC.8.2.4  Students will use a variety of materials and scientific instruments to conduct explorations, investigations and experiments of the natural world (e.g., barometer, anemometer, microscope, computer).
SC.8.2.5  Students will demonstrate safe techniques for handling, manipulating and caring for science materials, equipment, natural specimens and living organisms.

SC.8.2.6  Students will utilize experimentation to demonstrate scientific processes and thinking skills (e.g., formulating questions, predicting, forming hypotheses, quantifying, identifying dependent and independent variables).
SC.8.2.7  Students will construct and use charts, graphs and tables to organize, display, interpret, analyze and explain data.
SC.8.2.8  Students will use appropriate technology solutions to gather, graph and interpret data and analyze information.
SC.8.2.9  Students will use inferential reasoning to make logical conclusions from collected data.

SC.9.2.1  Students will model and exhibit the skills, attitudes and/or values of scientific inquiry (e.g., curiosity, logic, objectivity, openness, skepticism, appreciation, diligence, integrity, ethical practice, fairness, creativity).
SC.9.2.2  Students will demonstrate ethical practices for science (e.g., established research protocol, accurate record keeping, replication of results and peer review).
SC.9.2.3  Students will apply scientific approaches to seek solutions for personal and societal issues.
SC.9.2.4  Students will properly and safely manipulate equipment, materials, chemicals, organisms and models.
SC.9.2.5  Students will conduct explorations in a variety of environments (e.g., laboratories, museums, libraries, parks and other outdoors locations).

SC.9.2.6  Students will use appropriate technology solutions (e.g., computer, CBL, probe interfaces, software) to measure and collect data; interpret data; analyze and/or report data; interact with simulations; conduct research; and to present and communicate conclusions.

SC.9.2.7  Students will demonstrate science processes within a problem solving setting (e.g., observing, measuring, calculating, communicating, comparing, ordering, categorizing, classifying, relating, hypothesizing, predicting, inferring, considering alternatives and applying).

SC.9.2.8  Students will design, conduct, evaluate and revise experiments (e.g., identify questions and concepts that guide investigations; design investigations; identify independent and dependent variables in experimental investigations; manipulate variables to extend experimental activities; use technology and mathematics to improve investigations and communications; formulate and revise scientific explanations and models using logic and evidence; recognize alternative explanations; communicate and defend a scientific argument).

SC.10.2.1 Students will  model and exhibit the skills, attitudes and/or values of scientific inquiry (e.g., curiosity, logic, objectivity, openness, skepticism, appreciation, diligence, integrity, ethical practice, fairness, creativity).
SC.10.2.2 Students will  demonstrate ethical practices for science (e.g., established research protocol, accurate record keeping, replication of results and peer review).
SC.10.2.3 Students will  apply scientific approaches to seek solutions for personal and societal issues.
SC.10.2.4 Students will  properly and safely manipulate equipment, materials, chemicals, organisms and models.
SC.10.2.5 Students will  conduct explorations in a variety of environments (e.g., laboratories, museums, libraries, parks and other outdoors locations).

SC.10.2.6 Students will  use appropriate technology solutions (e.g., computer, CBL, probe interfaces, software) to measure and collect data; interpret data; analyze and/or report data; interact with simulations; conduct research; and present and communicate conclusions.

SC.10.2.7 Students will  demonstrate science processes within a problem solving setting (e.g., observing, measuring, calculating, communicating, comparing, ordering, categorizing, classifying, relating, hypothesizing, predicting, inferring, considering alternatives, and applying).

SC.10.2.8  Students will design, conduct, evaluate and revise experiments (e.g., identify questions and concepts that guide investigations; design investigations; identify independent and dependent variables in experimental investigations; manipulate variables to extend experimental activities; use technology and mathematics to improve investigations and communications; formulate and revise scientific explanations and models using logic and evidence; recognize alternative explanations; communicate and defend a scientific argument).

text:
Standard 3: Unifying Themes (SC.S.3)
  • demonstrate an understanding of interdependent themes present in the natural and designed world (e.g., systems, order and organization; evidence, models and explanation; constancy, change, and measurement; equilibrium and evolution; form and function),
  • demonstrate the ability to identify, construct, test, analyze and evaluate systems, models and changes, and
  • demonstrate the ability to draw conclusions about and predict changes in natural and designed systems.

children.text: Unifying Themes Objectives
SC.K.3.1 Students will  recognize that models are representations of real things.
SC.K.3.2  Students will observe that change occurs gradually, repetitively, or randomly within the environment.
SC.1.3.1 Students will identify that systems are made of parts that interact with one another.
SC.1.3.2 Students will use models as representations of real things.
SC.2.3.1 Students will identify that systems are made of parts that interact with one another.
SC.2.3.2 Students will use models as representations of real things.
SC.2.3.3 Students will observe that changes occur gradually, repetitively, or randomly within the environment.
SC.3.3.1 Students will identify that systems are made of parts that interact with one another.
SC.3.3.2 Students will use models as representations of real things.
SC.3.3.3 Students will observe that changes occur gradually, repetitively, or randomly within the environment and question causes of changes.
SC.3.3.4 Students will given a set of objects, group or order the objects according to an established scheme (e.g., celestial objects, patterns of motion, constellations).
SC.3.3.5 Students will given a set of events, objects, shapes, designs, or numbers, find patterns of constancy or regularity.
SC.4.3.1 Students will identify that systems are made of parts that interact with one another.
SC.4.3.2 Students will use models as representations of real things.
SC.4.3.3 Students will observe that changes occur gradually, repetitively, or randomly within the environment and question causes of changes.
SC.4.3.4 Students will given a set of objects, group or order the objects according to an established scheme.
SC.4.3.5 Students will given a set of events, objects, shapes, designs, or numbers, find patterns of constancy or regularity.
SC.5.3.1 Students will  compare and contrast the relationship between the parts of a system to the whole system (e.g., take a part or build mechanical, electrical, or biological systems).
SC.5.3.2 Students will  construct a variety of useful models of an object, event, or process.
SC.5.3.3  Students will compare and contrast changes that occur in an object or a system to its original state.

SC.5.3.4 Students will  identify the influence that a variation in scale will have on the way an object or system works. (e.g., cooling rates of different-sized containers of water, strength of different-sized constructions from the same material, flight characteristics of different-sized model airplanes).
SC.6.3.1  Students will compare and contrast the relationship between the parts of a system to the whole system (e.g., take apart or build mechanical, electrical, or biological systems).
SC.6.3.2  Students will construct a variety of useful models of an object, event, or process.
SC.6.3.3  Students will compare and contrast changes that occur in an object or a system to its original state.

SC.6.3.4  Students will identify the influence that a variation in scale will have on the way an object or system works. (e.g., cooling rates of different-sized containers of water, strength of different-sized constructions from the same material, flight characteristics of different-sized model airplanes).
SC.7.3.1  Students will compare and contrast the relationship between the parts of a system to the whole system (e.g., take apart or build mechanical, electrical or biological systems).
SC.7.3.2 Students will  construct a variety of useful models of an object, event or process.
SC.7.3.3 Students will  compare and contrast changes that occur in an object or a system to its original state.

SC.7.3.4 Students will  identify the influence that a variation in scale will have on the way an object or system works. (e.g., cooling rates of different-sized containers of water, strength of different-sized constructions from the same material, flight characteristics of different-sized model airplanes).
SC.8.3.1 Students will  compare and contrast the relationship between the parts of a system to the whole system (e.g., take apart or build mechanical, electrical, or biological systems).
SC.8.3.2 Students will  construct a variety of useful models of an object, event, or process.
SC.8.3.3 Students will  compare and contrast changes that occur in an object or a system to its original state.

SC.8.3.4 Students will  identify the influence that a variation in scale will have on the way an object or system works. (e.g., cooling rates of different-sized containers of water, strength of different-sized constructions from the same material, flight characteristics of different-sized model airplanes).

SC.9.3.1 Students will  analyze systems to understand the natural and designed world; use systems analysis to make predictions about behaviors in systems; recognize order in units of matter, objects or events.
SC.9.3.2 Students will  apply evidence from models to make predictions about interactions and changes in systems.
SC.9.3.3 Students will  measure changes in systems using graphs and equations relating these to rate, scale, patterns, trends and cycles.
SC.9.3.4 Students will  understand that different characteristics, properties or relationships within a system might change as its dimensions are increased or decreased (e.g., scale up, scale down).

SC.10.3.1 Students will  analyze systems to understand the natural and designed world; use systems analysis to make predictions about behaviors in systems; recognize order in units of matter, objects or events.
SC.10.3.2 Students will  apply evidence from models to make predictions about interactions and changes in systems.
SC.10.3.3 Students will  measure changes in systems using graphs and equations relating these to rate, scale, patterns, trends and cycles.
SC.10.3.4 Students will  understand that different characteristics, properties or relationships within a system might change as its dimensions are increased or decreased (e.g., scale up, scale down).

text:
Standard 4: Science Subject Matter/Concepts (SC.S.4)
  • demonstrate knowledge, understanding and applications of scientific facts, concepts, principles, theories and models as delineated in the objectives,
  • demonstrate an understanding of the interrelationships among physics, chemistry, biology and the earth and space sciences, and
  • apply knowledge, understanding and skills of science subject matter/concepts to daily life experiences.

children.text: Science Subject Matter/Concepts Objectives
Characteristics of Organisms
SC.K.4.1  Student will using the five senses, identify living and non-living things.
SC.1.4.1 Student will classify objects as living or non-living.
SC.1.4.2 Student will identify that most living things need water, food, light and air.
SC.2.4.1 Student will identify that plants and animals have different structures.

SC.2.4.2 Student will identify the structures of physical characteristics of living things and explain their functions (e.g., wings for flying, fins for swimming; roots for support and obtaining water).
SC.3.4.1 Student will identify the structures of living things, including their systems and explain their functions (e.g., roots absorb water, circulatory system to move materials).
SC.4.4.1 Student will describe the different characteristics of plants and animals which help them to survive in different niches and environments.
SC.4.4.2 Student will associate the behaviors of living organisms to external and internal influences (e.g., hunger, climate, seasons).
SC.4.4.3 Student will identify and classify variations in structures of living things including their systems and explain their functions (e.g., skeletons, teeth, plant needles, leaves).
Life Cycles of Organisms
SC.K.4.2 Student will  observe the movement, growth and changes in plants and animals.
SC.1.4.3 Student will recognize changes in life cycle of living organisms.
SC.1.4.4 Student will identify the parts of growing plants as they develop.
SC.2.4.3 Student will sequence pictures of events to illustrate the changes in the life cycle of plants and animals.
SC.2.4.4 Student will relate observations of the butterfly's life cycle to student's own growth and change.
SC.3.4.2 Student will observe, measure and record changes in living things (e.g., growth and development, variations within species).
SC.4.4.4 Student will compare and sequence changes in plant and animal life cycles.

SC.4.4.5 Student will understand that plants and animals closely resemble their parents and that some characteristics are inherited from the parents and others result from interaction with the environment.
Organisms and Environments
SC.K.4.3  Student will observe models of plants and animals in different environments (e.g., terrariums, aquariums, animals and plants in a forest, pond, field).
SC.1.4.5 Student will depict movement of living things in air, water and on land. (e.g., birds flying, fish swimming, worms burrowing in soil).
SC.2.4.5 Student will observe and compare simple models of different kinds of habitats, including a forest and a stream.

SC.3.4.3 Student will compare physical characteristics and behaviors of living organisms and explain how they are adapted to a specific environment (e.g., beaks and feet in birds, seed dispersal, camouflage, different types of flowers).

SC.3.4.4 Student will observe and describe relationships among organisms in an ecosystem (e.g., sequencing food chains, behavior, adaptations, factors that effect populations, predator-prey relationships).
SC.4.4.6 Student will identify human uses of plants and animals (e.g., food sources, medicines).
SC.4.4.7 Student will describe environmental barriers to the migration of animals.
SC.4.4.8 Student will construct and explain models of habitats, food chains, and food webs.
Properties of Objects and Materials

SC.K.4.4  Student will describe, compare, sort and group objects in terms of what they are made of (clay, cloth, paper, metal, etc.) and their physical properties of size, shape, color, weight or texture.
SC.K.4.5  Student will identify liquids and solids.
SC.1.4.6 Student will recognize that materials are composed of smaller parts that may be seen with a magnifier.
SC.1.4.7 Student will recognize that materials can be recycled and used again, sometimes in different forms.
SC.1.4.8 Student will recognize that water can be a solid or a liquid, and can change from one form to another.
SC.1.4.9 Student will predict and investigate the buoyancy of objects in water.
SC.2.4.6 Student will identify materials as a solid, a liquid or a gas and recognize that matter can change from one state to another.
SC.2.4.7 Student will demonstrate that solids, liquids and gases take up space.
SC.3.4.5 Student will relate the buoyancy of an object to its density.
SC.3.4.6 Student will identify physical and chemical properties.
SC.3.4.7 Student will relate changes in states of matter to changes in temperature.
SC.3.4.8 Student will investigate the dissolving of solids in liquids.
SC.4.4.9 Student will investigate how properties can be used to identify substances.
SC.4.4.10 Student will investigate and compare the dissolving of different solids in a given liquid.
SC.4.4.11 Student will examine simple chemical changes (e.g., tarnishing, rusting, burning).
SC.4.4.12 Student will understand that materials including air mass, take up space and are made of parts that are too small to be seen without magnification.
SC.4.4.13 Student will identify various changes in states of matter to heat loss or gain.
SC.4.4.14 Student will investigate variables that affect the rate of evaporation of a liquid.
SC.4.4.15 Student will investigate the density of liquids.
SC.5.4.9 Student will  explain that the mass of a material is conserved whether it is together, in parts, or in a different state.
SC.5.4.10 Student will  recognize that elements are composed of only one type of matter.
SC.5.4.11 Student will  using the periodic table, identify common elements according to their symbols.
SC.5.4.12  Student will identify substances by their relative densities (e.g., floating; sinking).
Light, Heat, Electricity and Magnetism
SC.K.4.6  Student will identify colors
SC.K.4.7 Student will  explore changes in energy (e.g., hot/cold and light/dark).
SC.K.4.8  Student will explore magnetic properties of objects.
SC.1.4.10 Student will classify objects as magnetic or non-magnetic.
SC.1.4.11 Student will observe and record shadows at different times of the day.
SC.2.4.8 Student will demonstrate that a magnet can attract or repel objects.
SC.2.4.9 Student will recognize that some materials and colors conduct heat better than others.
SC.2.4.10 Student will demonstrate that a shadow is cast when an object blocks light.
SC.3.4.9 Student will investigate the absorption, reflection and refraction of light by objects.
SC.3.1.10 Student will relate how the color of an object is based upon the absorption or reflection of light.
SC.4.4.16 Student will identify different forms of energy and describe energy transformations that occur between them (e.g., electrical to heat, light to mechanical).
SC.4.4.17 Student will examine types and properties of waves (e.g., transverse, longitudinal, frequency, wavelengths).
SC.4.4.18 Student will investigate static electricity and conductors/nonconductors of electricity.
SC.4.4.19 Student will construct simple electrical circuits.
SC.4.4.20 Student will understand the relationship between a compass and a magnetic field.
SC.5.4.13 Student will  analyze diagrams of electrical circuits.
SC.5.4.14  Student will use SI (metric) measurement units of volts, amps and watts as they apply to electricity.
SC.5.4.15 Student will  investigate the properties of an electromagnet.
Position and Motion of Objects
SC.K.4.9  Student will explore the different ways objects can be moved (e.g., straight, circular, fast, slow).
SC.1.4.12 Student will describe the changes in the motion of objects (e.g., slowing, speeding up, curving).
SC.1.4.13 Student will demonstrate that sounds are produced by vibrations.
SC.2.4.11 Student will compare the effects of force on the motion of an object.
SC.2.4.12 Student will recognize that sound can change in pitch and volume.
SC.3.4.11 Student will recognize that it takes work to move objects over a distance.
SC.3.4.12 Student will recognize that speed, distance, and time are interrelated.
SC.3.4.13 Student will recognize that the greater a force is exerted on an object, the greater the change of its motion will be.
SC.3.4.14 Student will identify examples of potential and kinetic energy.
SC.4.4.21 Student will relate motion of an object to its frame of reference.
SC.4.4.22 Student will predict and investigate the motion of an object if the applied force is changed.
SC.4.4.23 Student will explore that sounds are produced by vibrating objects and columns of air and explore the relationship between frequency and pitch of sound.
SC.4.4.24 Student will investigate the change in the length, tension, or thickness of the vibrating object on the frequency of vibration (e.g., string, wire, rubber band).
SC.5.4.16 Student will  describe how the variables of gravity and friction affect the motion of objects.
SC.5.4.17  Student will compare and contrast the change in length, tension, or thickness of a vibrating object on the frequency of vibration.
Changes in Earth and Sky
SC.K.4.10  Student will observe and record daily changes in weather (e.g., clouds, air temperature).
SC.1.4.14 Student will observe, identify and record changes in weather and effects on living organisms.
SC.1.4.15 Student will recognize that the sun, moon, and stars appear to move.
SC.2.4.13 Student will examine changes in the earth's surface (e.g., weathering, erosion).
SC.2.4.14 Student will identify the effects of wind movement.
SC.2.4.15 Student will observe and describe different types of precipitation.
SC.2.4.16 Student will compare seasonal changes.
SC.2.4.17 Student will explain how the rotation of the Earth on its axis causes day and night.
SC.3.4.15 Student will identify fossils as a record of time (e.g., what organisms once lived on Earth, where they lived).
SC.3.4.16 Student will explore the eroding of different materials by water and wind (e.g., sand, mud pile and rocks).
SC.3.4.17 Student will describe how volcanoes and earthquakes change the Earth.
SC.4.4.25 Student will become familiar with the geologic time scale.
SC.4.4.26 Student will locate and identify patterns of stars and their seasonal changes.
SC.4.4.27 Student will compare and explain the relative time differences to erode materials (e.g., a sand pile, mud pile, rock pile).
SC.4.4.28 Student will investigate the cause and effects of volcanoes, earthquakes and landslides.
SC.4.4.29 Student will interpret a weather chart or map.
Objects in the Sky
SC.K.4.11  Student will identify objects in the day and night sky (e.g., moon, stars, sun).
SC.1.4.16 Student will observe and discuss the importance of objects in the day and night sky.
SC.2.4.18 Student will understand that the moon has phases.
SC.3.4.18 Student will recognize the relative movement of the Sun and Moon in relationship to the Earth's position.
SC.3.4.19 Student will describe the similarities and differences among the planets.
SC.4.4.30 Student will identify the sun as a star.
SC.4.4.31 Student will describe the orbits of the Sun and Moon.
SC.4.4.32 Students will describe and explain the planets orbital paths.
Properties of Earth Materials
SC.K.4.12  Students will observe and compare differences in earth materials.
SC.1.4.17 Students will use a model to compare land and water features on the Earth.
SC.1.4.18 Students will identify important uses of air.
SC.1.4.19 Students will investigate and compare the properties of soil (e.g., sand, clay, humus).
SC.2.4.19 Students will describe how fossils are formed.
SC.2.4.20 Students will match a fossil or a picture of a fossil, with a picture of its original organism (e.g., dinosaur bones, shell, fern).
SC.3.4.20 Students will identify properties of minerals and recognize that rocks are composed of different minerals.
SC.3.4.21 Students will  explain how igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks are formed.
SC.3.4.22 Students will identify geographical features using a model or map (e.g., mountains, rivers, valleys, lakes, glaciers, volcanoes).
SC.3.4.23 Students will describe the layers of the Earth and their various features.
SC.4.4.33 Students will describe the rock cycle.
SC.4.4.34 Students will explain the relationship between the rate of cooling and crystal size of igneous rocks.
SC.4.4.35 Students will compare ocean water and fresh water.
SC.5.4.1 Students will  demonstrate an understanding of the interconnections of biological, earth and space, and physical science concepts.
Structure and Function in Living Systems
SC.5.4.2 Students will  identify and explain common energy conversions in cycles of matter including photosynthesis and carbon dioxide cycle.
SC.5.4.3 Students will  identify the structures of living organisms and explain their function.
SC.5.4.4 Students will  observe and identify cells of organisms using a microscope.
SC.6.4.2 Students will  describe the interactions of various cycles that provide energy through decomposition, photosynthesis, respiration, transpiration in the food web; nitrogen cycle.
SC.6.4.3 Students will  classify living organisms according to their structure and functions.
SC.6.4.4 Students will  compare the similarities of internal features of organisms which can be used to infer relatedness.
SC.6.4.5 Students will  explain how abiotic and biotic factors affect the interdependence among organisms.
SC.6.4.6 Students will  construct models of plant and animal cells which show the basic parts (e.g., cytoplasm, cell wall, cell membrane, nucleus, chloroplasts).
SC.7.4.2 Students will  identify and describe disease causing organisms (such as bacteria, viruses, protozoa, fungi) and the diseases they cause.
SC.7.4.3 Students will  explain how the skeletal, muscular and integumentary systems work together in the human body.
SC.7.4.4 Students will  compare the level of organization of cells, tissues and organs in living things.
SC.7.4.5 Students will  construct simple keys to differentiate among living things with similar characteristics.
SC.7.4.6 Students will  use pictures to show cyclical processes in nature (e.g., water cycle, nitrogen cycle, and carbon cycle).
SC.8.4.2 Students will  identify and explain the structures and functions of cell organelles.
SC.8.4.3 Students will  explain how the circulatory, respiratory and reproductive systems work together in the human body.
SC.8.4.4  Students will compare the variations in cells, tissues and organs of the circulatory, respiratory and reproductive systems of different organisms.
SC.8.4.5  Students will demonstrate how living cells obtain the essentials of life through chemical reactions of transpiration, respiration and photosynthesis.
Life Cycles of Organisms:  Reproduction and Heredity
SC.5.4.5 Students will  compare variations of plant growth and reproduction.
SC.6.4.7 Students will  compare growth patterns in different plants (e.g., mosses, ferns, perennials, biennials, woody plants, herbaceous plants).

SC.7.4.7 Students will  evaluate how the different adaptations and life cycles of plants and animals help them to survive in different niches and environments (e.g., inherited and acquired adaptations).
SC.7.4.8 Students will  analyze how changes in the environment have led to reproductive adaptations through natural selection.
SC.7.4.9 Students will  relate how an organism's behavior response is a combination of heredity and environment.
SC.7.4.10 Students will  analyze the differences in the growth, development and reproduction of flowering and nonflowering plants.
SC.8.4.6 Students will  analyze how behaviors of organisms lead to species continuity (e.g., reproductive/mating behaviors, seed dispersal).

SC.8.4.7 Students will  demonstrate the basic principles of genetics to include Mendel's laws, DNA, monohybrid crosses, production of sperm and egg, production of body cells, genes, chromosomes, inherited traits.
SC.8.4.8 Students will  examine how patterns of human development are similar to other vertebrates.
Populations and Ecosystems
SC.5.4.6 Students will  explain how the different characteristics of plants and animals help them to survive in different niches and environments including adaptations, natural selection, extinction.
SC.5.4.7 Students will  explore the extinction of a species due to environmental conditions.
SC.5.4.8 Students will  trace and describe the pathways of the sun's energy through producers, consumers and decomposers using food webs and pyramids.
SC.6.4.8  Students will demonstrate changes in populations of organisms due to limiting environmental factors (e.g., food supply, predators, disease, habitat).
SC.6.4.9 Students will  analyze the ecological consequences of human interactions with the environment (e.g., renewable and non-renewable resources).
SC.7.4.11 Students will  predict the trends of interdependent populations if one of the limiting factors is changed.
SC.7.4.12 Students will  evaluate the consequences of the introduction of chemicals into the ecosystem (e.g., environmental consequences, human health risks, mutations).
SC.8.4.9 Students will  group unknown organisms based on observable characteristics (e.g., use dichotomous keys).

SC.8.4.10 Students will  trace matter and energy flow in a food web as it goes from sunlight to producers to consumers, design an environment in which the chemical and energy needs for the growth, reproduction and development of plants are met (e.g., food pyramids, decomposition).
Structure of the Earth System
SC.5.4.18 Students will  describe the layers of the earth and their various features.
SC.5.4.19 Students will  identify and describe natural landforms, how they change and impact weather and climate.
SC.5.4.20 Students will  use a variety of instruments and sources to collect and display weather data to describe weather patterns (e.g., temperatures, wind direction, wind speed, precipitation).
SC.5.4.21 Students will  compare and explain the different rates of weathering, erosion and deposition in certain materials.
SC.5.4.22 Students will  identify land features and elevations on a topographical map.
SC.5.4.23 Students will  identify resources as being renewable or non-renewable.
SC.6.4.25 Students will  track major atmospheric events.
SC.6.4.26 Students will  describe and demonstrate the forces and results of plate tectonics.
SC.7.4.26 Students will  depict and relate causes of tides, surfs and currents.
SC.7.4.27 Students will  examine the relationships among air masses, oceans, weather, convection currents and the sun's energy.
SC.7.4.28 Students will  interpret and create topographical maps.
SC.8.4.25 Students will  summarize problems related to water on earth as a life sustaining substance (e.g., quality and quantity of surface and ground water).
SC.8.4.26 Students will  identify the principle forces of plate tectonics and related geological events.
SC.8.4.27 Students will  relate global patterns of atmospheric movement on local weather and the impact of oceans on weather and climate.
Earth's History
SC.5.4.24 Students will  explore and explain how fossils and geologic features can be used to determine the relative age of rocks and rock layers.
SC.5.4.25 Students will  identify that the Earth is made of plates (plate tectonics).
SC.6.4.27 Students will  describe changes in the rock record due to geologic and physical events over time. (e.g., rock cycle as it relates to plate tectonics.).
SC.7.4.29 Students will  compare and contrast periods of geologic time using rocks and rock layers.
SC.8.4.28 Students will  relate rock formations to the types of fossil fuels.
SC.8.4.29 Students will  describe the factors involved in mining resources.
SC.8.4.30 Students will  construct and interpret rock layer models through stratigraphic interpretation.
SC.6.4.1 Students will  demonstrate an understanding of the interconnections of biological, earth and space and physical science concepts.
Structure and Properties of Matter
SC.6.4.10 Students will  classify and investigate properties and processes (changes) as either physical or chemical.
SC.6.4.11 Students will  investigate the composition of matter concluding that matter is composed of tiny particles and that the particles are the same for the same type of matter.
SC.6.4.12 Students will  investigate the formation and separation of simple mixtures.
SC.6.4.13 Students will  use indicators to identify substances as acidic, basic or neutral.
SC.6.4.14 Students will  identify the symbols of elements.
SC.6.4.15 Students will  use the periodic table to identify elements as solids, liquids and gases, metals or nonmetals.
SC.6.4.16 Students will  describe properties of matter (e.g., inertia, specific heat, malleability, melting point, density).
SC.7.4.13 Students will  differentiate among elements, compounds, homogeneous and heterogeneous mixtures.
SC.7.4.14  Students will evaluate types of solutions (e.g., solutes and solvents relative concentrations, conductivity, pH).
SC.8.4.11 Students will  use the periodic table to locate and classify elements as metallic, non-metallic or metalloid.
SC.8.4.12 Students will  trace the development of the model of the atom (e.g., Crookes, Thompson, Becquerel, Rutherford, Bohr).
SC.8.4.13 Students will  determine the number of protons, neutrons and electrons and use information to draw a Bohr model of the atom.
SC.8.4.14 Students will  assign an element to its chemical family on the periodic table and note similarities in outer energy level electrons within each family.
SC.8.4.15  Students will evaluate gaseous systems noting the variation in diffusion rates and examine the expansion of gases at elevated temperatures.
SC.9.4.11 Students will  using the element's position on the Periodic Table, predict physical and chemical properties.

SC.9.4.12  Students will describe the characteristics of radioactivity substances including alpha particles, beta particles and gamma rays; the half life of a radioactive isotope; a chain reaction; and differentiate between fission and fusion.
SC.9.4.13 Students will  investigate the relationship between the density of an object, its mass, and its volume.
SC.9.4.14 Students will  investigate physical states of matter including descriptions of the behavior of atoms and molecules in terms of the Kinetic Molecular Theory.
SC.10.4.17 Students will  investigate the properties of solutions including density, conductivity, solubility, concentration, pH and colligative properties.
Energy

SC.6.4.17 Students will  investigate the properties electromagnetic spectrum (e.g., wavelengths, frequencies, visible light); relate wave lengths and/or frequency to position on electromagnetic spectrum (e.g., colors, x-ray).
SC.6.4.18 Students will  identify factors affecting reflection and refraction (e.g., nature of surfaces, color, density of medium).
SC.6.4.19 Students will  explain absorption and reflection of light by different objects of various colors and textures (e.g., transparent, translucent, opaque, different colors).
SC.6.4.20 Students will  describe the flow of heat between objects (e.g., hot air rises, absorption and release of heat by metals).
SC.6.4.21 Students will  diagram simple parallel and series circuits (e.g., bulbs, battery, wires, switch).
SC.7.4.17 Students will  describe the behavior of individual particles and verify the conservation of matter (e.g., melting and freezing of pure substances).
SC.7.4.18 Students will  trace the energy flow during phase changes
SC.7.4.19 Students will  define characteristics of light and sound waves and describe how sound is perceived by the ear and light is perceived by the eye.
SC.7.4.20 Students will  investigate application of lenses to science (e.g., microscopes, telescopes, magnifying glass, periscopes).
SC.7.4.21 Students will  identify characteristics of AC and DC circuits.
SC.7.4.22 Students will  explain conservation of matter and energy qualitatively and recognize that energy can be changed from one form to another.
SC.8.4.18 Students will  identify types of energy and their sources (e.g., petroleum refinement, windmills, geothermal).
SC.8.4.19 Students will  interpret and illustrate changes in waves as they pass through various mediums (e.g., sound through water and metal, light through thicknesses of glass).
SC.8.4.20 Students will  apply the conservation of energy theory to energy transformations (e.g., electrical/heat, heat/mechanical).
SC.8.4.21 Students will  quantitatively represent work, power, pressure (e.g., W=fd, P=W/t, pressure =force/area).
SC.9.4.18 Students will  identify, describe and differentiate various forms of energy and energy transformations.
SC.9.4.19 Students will  relate absorption and dissipation of heat to the composition of a material.
SC.9.4.20 Students will  demonstrate and diagram a magnetic field using bar magnets.

SC.9.4.21 Students will  hypothesize and experiment when different components are substituted in an electrical circuit; define and solve electrical problems involving potential difference, Ohm's Law and power.

SC.10.4.19 Students will  investigate the relationships among temperature, pressure and volume in gases and interpret graphs that depict these relationships (e.g., Charles' Law, Boyle's Law, Gay-Lussac's Law).
SC.10.4.20 Students will  investigate and measure changes in thermal energy in physical and chemical changes.
SC.10.4.21 Students will  compare and contrast the characteristics and uses of waves in various parts of the electromagnetic spectrum; calculate the frequency of a particular wavelength.
SC.10.4.22  Students will summarize the relationship between frequency and speed (e.g., Doppler effect).
SC.10.4.23 Students will  qualitatively explain the relationship between electricity and magnetism and describe how electrical components of a circuit function.
SC.10.4.24  Students will qualitatively and quantitatively describe the conservation of energy (e.g., thermal, chemical, mechanical).
Motions and Forces
SC.6.4.22 Students will  interpret the relationship of mass to gravitational force (e.g., larger the mass the larger the gravitational force, the closer the objects the stronger the force).
SC.6.4.23 Students will  examine simple machines and the forces involved; apply the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces on motion of objects.
SC.6.4.24 Students will  explain motion in terms of frames of reference and analyze graphs depicting motion and predicted future motion.
SC.7.4.23 Students will  perform experiments with simple machines to demonstrate the relationship between forces and distance; use vectors to represent motion.
SC.7.4.24 Students will  explain the effect of gravity on falling objects (e.g., g= 9.8m/s², object dropped on earth and on moon).
SC.7.4.25 Students will  analyze motion graphically and use vectors to represent direction of motion.
SC.8.4.22 Students will  graph and interpret the relationships (e.g., distance versus time, speed versus time, acceleration versus time).
SC.8.4.23 Students will  describe Newton's Laws of Motion; identify examples; illustrate qualitatively and quantitatively drawing vector quantities.
SC.8.4.24 Students will  illustrate quantitatively mechanical advantage of simple machines.
SC.9.4.22 Students will  relate the forces between charged objects to the charge on the objects and the distance between them.
SC.9.4.23 Students will  review foundational concepts of kinematics (e.g., speed-distance-time relationships, graphs) and dynamics (e.g., Newton's Laws, simple machines).
SC.9.4.24 Students will  experiment with a pendulum to determine which variables (amplitude, mass, length) will affect the motion of the pendulum.

SC.9.4.25 Students will  investigate types of waves and their properties including interference, diffraction, refraction, resonance; differences and similarities between transverse and longitudinal waves; wave equation to determine the relationships among speed, wavelength and frequency.
SC.10.4.25 Students will  apply Newton's Laws of Motion to depict the relationship among rate, force, momentum, work, and time using kinematics graph and mathematical models.
SC.10.4.26 Students will  describe and quantify how machines can provide mechanical advantages.
SC.10.4.27 Students will  determine the effect of different forces on vibrating systems (e.g., pendulums, springs).
SC.10.4.28 Students will  demonstrate qualitative and quantitative understanding of pressure in various systems (e.g., water pipes, circuits, blood vessels).
Earth and the Solar System
SC.6.4.28 Students will  recognize the phases of the Moon.
SC.6.4.29 Students will  investigate models of Earth-Moon-Sun relationships (e.g., gravity, time, tides).
SC.6.4.30 Students will  compare the Earth's tilt and revolution to the seasonal changes.
SC.7.4.30 Students will  explain and model using manipulatives how the Earth's tilt and revolution determine the seasonal changes and weather patterns.
SC.7.4.31 Students will  recognize the changes involved in the life cycle of a star.
SC.7.4.32 Students will describe and compare the physical characteristics of celestial objects.
SC.7.4.33 Students will  compare the characteristics of the members of our solar system.
SC.8.4.31 Students will  recognize societal concerns with exploration and colonization of space.
SC.8.4.32 Students will  diagram the motions of the Sun, Moon and Earth and explain the phenomena associated with these motions (e.g., glacial periods, eclipses, tides, meteor showers).
SC.8.4.33  Students will compare and contrast the orbits of planets and comets.
SC.8.4.34 Students will  compare and contrast the different types of galaxies (e.g., shape, size, components).
SC.7.4.1 Students will  demonstrate an understanding of the interconnections of biological, earth and space and physical science concepts.
Chemical Reaction
SC.7.4.15 Students will  study chemical reactions involving acids and bases by monitoring color changes of indicator(s) and identifying the salt formed in the neutralization reaction.
SC.7.4.16 Students will  write word equations to describe chemical reactions.

SC.8.4.16 Students will  conduct and classify chemical reactions by reaction type (synthesis, decomposition, single replacement or double replacement); energy type (endothermic and exothermic); and write word equations for the chemical reactions.
SC.8.4.17 Students will  identify chemical reaction factors that might affect the reaction rates including catalysts, temperature changes, light energies and particle size.
SC.9.4.15 Students will  write formulas and name compounds given oxidation numbers of monatomic and polyatomic ions.
SC.9.4.16 Students will  identify the various types of chemical bonds and the resulting compounds that are formed (e.g., ionic, nonpolar covalent, polar covalent).
SC.9.4.17 Students will  experimentally determine the products of chemical reactions; write balanced chemical equations; classify type of reaction; and describe energy changes.
SC.10.4.18  Students will differentiate among physical, chemical and nuclear changes and reactions.
SC.8.4.1  Students will demonstrate an understanding of the interconnections of biological, earth and space, and physical science concepts.
SC.9.4.1  Students will demonstrate an understanding of the interconnections of biological, earth/space and physical science concepts.
The Cell and Molecular Basis for Heredity

SC.9.4.2  Students will analyze and explain the principles of genetics (e.g., monohybrid and dihybrid crosses, mutations, genotypes, phenotypes, X and Y chromosomes, multiple alleles, DNA, probability, diversity).
SC.9.4.3 Students will  illustrate meiosis and mitosis and relate to chromosome number and production of sperm, egg and body cells.
SC.10.4.2  Students will identify and explain the structure and function of cell organelles (e.g., Golgi bodies, endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, chloroplasts, ribosomes, lysosomes, vacuoles).
SC.10.4.3 Students will  compare the variations in cells, tissues and organs of different organisms (e.g., endocrine, nervous, digestion and immune systems).
SC.10.4.4  Students will identify mechanisms for the movement of materials into and out of cells (e.g., active and passive transport, endo- and exocytosis).
SC.10.4.5  Students will explore the discovery of DNA and its structure by constructing a model to demonstrate the nucleotide bonding and the double helix structure.

SC.10.4.6  Students will relate the role of DNA analysis to genetic disorders, forensic science, molecular genetics, and biotechnology (e.g., protein synthesis, heredity, cell division, cellular functions).
SC.10.4.7  Students will review principles of genetics (e.g., number of chromosomes, mutations, crossover, Punnett squares, linkage).
The Interdependence of Organisms
SC.9.4.4  Students will mathematically illustrate changes in populations of organisms.
SC.9.4.5  Students will identify and describe microscopic organisms and foreign substances in the environment and their harmful effects (e.g., microorganisms, mutagens, carcinogens).
SC.9.4.6  Students will design an environment that demonstrates the interdependence of plants and animals (e.g., energy and chemical cycles, adaptations of structures and behaviors).
Matter, Energy, and Organization in Living Systems
SC.9.4.7  Students will explain how excretory, digestive systems work together in the human body.
SC.9.4.8  Students will identify and compare the structure and function of cell, tissues and systems of different organisms.
SC.9.4.9  Students will identify the organisms and the chemical processes involved in the decay of materials.
SC.9.4.10  Students will trace the transfer of matter and energy in the chemical/molecular processes of photosynthesis, respiration and fermentation.

SC.10.4.12  Students will construct diagrams showing energy flow and cycles of matter between chemical and biological systems including photosynthesis, stored chemical energy, decomposition, carbon and nitrogen cycles.
SC.10.4.13  Students will explain how the nervous, endocrine and immune systems work together in the human body.
SC.10.4.14  Students will review the needs of growing plants and the environments supplying those needs.
SC.10.4.15  Students will review factors that affect succession, populations and communities (e.g., use maps, graphs, charts, tables).
SC.10.4.16  Students will trace matter and energy flow through the respiration process (e.g., ATP, carbon, oxygen, water).
Energy in the Earth System
SC.9.4.26  Students will investigate formation and destruction of landforms.
SC.9.4.27  Students will demonstrate the relationships of temperature, air pressure, wind speed, wind direction and humidity as elements of weather.
SC.9.4.28  Students will compare and analyze the characteristics of oceans, including their lateral and vertical motions.

SC.10.4.29  Students will relate the characteristics and behavior of mechanical waves to earth processes (e.g., explain the formation of water waves as a function of wind velocity, duration, and fetch).
SC.10.4.30  Students will relate the cause of tides to their height and frequency.
SC.10.4.31  Students will investigate effects of geological events on weather and climate (e.g., ocean currents and atmospheric conditions).
SC.10.4.32  Students will observe and describe the effects of water on the earth's surface (e.g., changes in particle size, slope, velocity).
SC.10.4.33  Students will relate Earth's electromagnetic field to the dynamics of the magnetosphere.
SC.10.4.34  Students will discuss theories for the causes of plate tectonics.
Geochemical Cycles
SC.9.4.29  Students will employ a variety of tests to identify common rock-forming minerals.
SC.9.4.30  Students will analyze and describe common rock samples using grain size and shape, and mineral composition.
SC.9.4.31  Students will use models to describe interactive cycles such as the water, the nitrogen and the carbon dioxide cycles.
SC.10.4.35  Students will discuss physical and chemical relationships between minerals in rock cycle.
Origin and Changes in the Earth Systems and Universe
SC.9.4.32  Students will examine how scientists use seismographic evidence in determining structure and composition of the Earth's interior.
SC.9.4.33  Students will determine the relative age of materials using time-stratigraphic and bio-stratigraphic relationships.
SC.9.4.34  Students will estimate the absolute age of materials using existing radio isotopic data.
SC.9.4.35  Students will describe the effects of the movement of subsurface water.
SC.9.4.36  Students will relate changes in the Earth's surface to the motion of lithospheric plates.
SC.9.4.37  Students will summarize and discuss the evidentiary basis for the Theory of Plate Tectonics.
SC.9.4.38  Students will research and describe the life cycles of various stellar types.
SC.9.4.39  Students will interpret topographic maps, weather maps and charts, and astronomical models such as solar systems, galaxies, constellations, stellar types and stellar evolution.
SC.10.4.36  Students will investigate fossils as evidence for evolution and indicators of paleo-environments.
SC.10.4.37  Students will compare and contrast morphological features of fossils to present-day organisms.
SC.10.4.38  Students will use fossil evidence to estimate the relative and absolute ages of rock layers.
SC.10.4.39  Students will compare and contrast the characteristics of Earth and the other planets relative to their distance from the Sun.
SC.10.4.40  Students will interpret apparent motion of constellations and their relationship to the rotation of the earth.
SC.10.4.1  Students will demonstrate an understanding of the interconnections of biological, earth and space and physical science concepts.
Evolution and Interdependence of Organisms
SC.10.4.8  Students will compare the embryonic development of invertebrate and vertebrate animals (e.g., ontogeny and phylogeny, diversity, taxonomy).
SC.10.4.9  Students will construct and manipulate models which show variations in living things.
SC.10.4.10  Students will recognize that fossil records provide a scientific explanation for variation in the species and common ancestors.
SC.10.4.11  Students will relate the role of natural selection to the development, diversity and or extinction of a species.

text:
Standard 5: Scientific Design and Application (SC.S.5)
  • demonstrate an understanding of the interdependence between science and technology,
  • demonstrate the ability to distinguish between natural and man-made objects,
  • demonstrate abilities of technological design, and
  • demonstrate the ability to utilize technology to gather data and communicate designs, results and conclusions.

children.text: Scientific Design and Application Objectives.
SC.K.5.1 Students will observe the uses of tools and appliances at home and at play.
SC.1.5.1 Students will distinguish between natural and man-made objects.
SC.2.5.1 Students will recognize that common objects and events incorporate science (e.g., CD players, Velcro, weather) to solve human problems and enhance the quality of life.
SC.3.5.1 Students will cite examples of the uses of science and technology in common daily events and in the community.
SC.3.5.2 Students will explain a simple problem and identify a specific solution describing the use of tools and/or materials to solve the problem or to complete the task.
SC.4.5.1 Students will identify and explain a simple problem or task to be completed; identify a specific solution; and list task requirements.
SC.4.5.2 Students will use an appropriate engineering design to solve a problem or complete a task.
SC.4.6.1 Students will recognize that a solution to one scientific problem often creates new problems (e.g., recycling, pollution, conservation, waste disposal, need for technology).

SC.4.6.2 Students will listen to and be tolerant of different viewpoints by engaging in collaborative activities and modifying ideas when new and valid information is presented from a variety of resources.
SC.4.6.3 Students will describe the positive and negative consequences of the application of technology on personal health and the environment.
SC.4.6.4 Students will develop respect and responsibility for the environment by engaging in conservation practices.
SC.5.5.1  Students will research everyday applications and interactions of science and technology.
SC.5.5.2  Students will implement engineering solutions for given tasks and measure their effectiveness.
SC.6.5.1  Students will given a set of attributes, produce a product or process and cite how design priorities (e.g., space, safety) and available materials impact the outcome.
SC.6.5.2  Students will evaluate the appropriateness of the materials and procedures in given engineering solutions.
SC.7.5.1  Students will make and compare different proposed solutions to an identified problem in light of specified criteria.
SC.7.5.2  Students will test and evaluate different types of materials and/or design approaches in building objects or completing tasks.
SC.8.5.1  Students will research applications of space technology in everyday life (e.g., Velcro, Teflon, weather satellites).
SC.8.5.2  Students will compare scientific inquiry and technological design processes.
SC.8.5.3  Students will explain why no technological design is perfect (e.g., constraints lead to tradeoffs).
SC.8.5.4  Students will design and construct engineering solutions to problems according to specified constraints.
SC.9.5.1  Students will identify the scientific concepts underlying simple technological innovations.
SC.9.5.2  Students will cite examples of the interdependence of science and technology (e.g., new technologies have lead to development of new scientific knowledge).
SC.9.5.3  Students will apply scientific skills and technological tools to design a solution that addresses a personal or societal need.
SC.9.5.4  Students will analyze the consequences of imposed constraints on an engineering solution.
SC.10.5.1  Students will investigate and analyze the interdependence of science and technology.
SC.10.5.2  Students will research and design solutions to a personal or a societal problem created by technology.
SC.10.5.3  Students will compare and test modifications to an engineering design.
SC.10.5.4 Students will utilize technology to communicate designs, results and conclusions.
SC.10.6.1  Students will investigate the effects of natural phenomena on the habitat and habitat change.
SC.10.6.2  Students will research current environmental issues (e.g., depletion of fossil fuels, global warming, destruction of rainforest pollution).
SC.10.6.3  Students will describe the impact of cultural, technological, and economic influences on the evolving nature of scientific thought and knowledge.
SC.10.6.4  Students will explore occupational opportunities in science and technology including the academic preparation necessary.
SC.10.6.5  Students will engage in decision making activities and actions to resolve science-technology-society issues.
